sections.heading: 1. Introduction: Nanoarchitectonics at Interfaces between Materials and Life
sections.text:
Most of important demands in current society such as highly functional materials production,[1] efficient energy handling,[2] environmental protection[3] and advanced biomedical operation,[4] undoubtedly rely on rational design and synthesis of materials systems with nanoscale structural precisions. In addition to considerable successes in nanotechnology for observations and manipulations with nano-level resolutions, methodological paradigm shift to architect functional materials from nanoscale units is required to satisfy demanded technological advancements. This task will be taken by an emerging concept, nanoarchitectonics.[5]
The nanoarchitectonics concept was originally proposed by Masakazu Aono.[6] It combines nanotechnology with fabrication essences from various research fields such as supramolecular chemistry, materials science, and biological chemistry. In the nanoarchitectonics procedures, functional materials and systems can be architected with various actions and processes including atomic/molecular manipulation, organic synthesis, self-assembly/self-organization and structural regulation upon application of external physical stimuli (Figure 1). Because of high generality of the nanoarchitectonics concept, this concept is now accepted by various research fields including materials production,[7] energy technology,[8] and environmental sciences.[9] Unlike structure constructions in macroscopic scale, uncontrollable or unexpected factors such as quantum effect, statistical uncertainties, and complicated mutual interactions between numerous components are unavoidable in nanoscale regions. Therefore, balanced harmonization of several interac-
tions is required in nanoarchitectonics strategy for creation of functional materials.[10]
The above-mentioned features on the harmonization of actions in constructions of functional systems from nanoscale units are commonly observed in biological systems, where assembled systems are working in harmony of their interactions under certain thermal fluctuations. Therefore, applications of the nanoarchitectonics concept to bio-related science and technology have increasingly attracted research attentions.[11] For example, Stulz described the nanoarchitectonics strategy for the construction of functional assemblies using porphyrin modified DNA in his Account article.[12] Peptide-based nanoarchitectonics was discussed by Yan and co-workers who summarized applications of self-assembled peptide nanoarchitectures in biomimetic photosystems, optical waveguiding by assembled peptide microtubes, and phototherapy.[13] Avinash and Govindaraju also emphasized the importance of the nanoarchitectonics concept for functional applications of assemblies of biomolecules such as lipids, nucleobases, carbohydrates, and

amino acids.[14] Nanoarchitectonics of thermo-responsive polymer brushes on protein adsorption and cell adhesion was reported by Uhlmann and co-workers.[15] They reported stimuli dependent fibrinogen adsorption and adhesion of human mesenchymal stem cells.
In our previous Focus Review in ChemNanoMat entitled ‘Interfaces Working for Biology: Solving Biological Mysteries and Opening Up Future Nanoarchitectonics’, critical roles of interface such as highly emphasized biomolecular recognitions, significantly altered physical properties and their contributions to possible scenario on origin of life were reported.[16] In addition, controls of living cells at interfacial environments were partially discussed as future nanoarchitectonics. As advanced stages of nanoarchitectonics strategies to living bio-systems, more progressed interfacial materials nanoarchitectonics for cell regulations are described in this Minireview. The contents described in this review are classified into (i) influences of physical mechanical factors such as elasticity and viscoelasticity on cell regulations at materials surfaces and liquid interfaces; (ii) regulation of cells upon dynamic surface natures, stimuli by chemicals and geometric factors; (iii) effects of surface structures prepared by microfabrications and assemblies of nanomaterials on cell regulations.

sections.heading: 2. Nanoarchitectonics for Cell: Physical Mechanical Factors
sections.text: As mentioned in several review articles, cell function and fate can be modulated by various nanoarchitectonics features of biomaterials.[17] Such modulations would regulate cell adhesions, and further cell phenotypes including migration, proliferation, and differentiation. Nanoarchitectonics of materials interfaces concerning with surface chemistry, geometry, and mechanical properties would affect cell function and fate. For example, cells sense interfacial properties of contacting materials, propagate signal and then translate the signaling information into cell fate decisions.[18] Therefore, designs and fabrications of interfacial materials nanoarchitectonics would be an important key methodology for stem cell biology and engineering. Effects of surface properties of contacting materials on cell fates have been investigated from various viewpoints.

sections.heading: 2.1. Mechanical Properties of Materials
sections.text:
As contributions of physical properties (not biochemical supplements), Discher and co-workers pioneered to investigate the direct effects of matrix elasticity on stem cell lineage specification (Figure 2).[19] Naive mesenchymal stem cells are highly sensitive to tissue-level elasticity to decide cell phenotypes type: brain-like soft material matrices for neurogenic, musclemimic stiffer matrices for myogenic, and collagenous bone indicative rigid matrices for osteogenic differentiation. Cell lineage commitments were determined by matrix elasticity after
Katsuhiko Ariga received his Ph.D. from Tokyo Institute of Technology in 1990. He is currently the Leader of the Supermolecules Group and Principal Investigator at the World Premier International Research Centre for Materials Nanoarchitectonics, NIMS. He has also been appointed as Professor at the University of Tokyo.
Xiaofang Jia received her Ph. D. from Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences in January 2015, and continued to work there as assistant professor until April 2016. Then she moved to the Ohio State University as postdoctoral fellow from May 2016. Now she works as a postdoctoral fellow in NIMS from October 2017.
Jingwen Song is a Ph.D. student of the University of Tokyo under the guidance of Professor Katsuhiko Ariga. she is currently studying in the Supermolecules Group at the World Premier International Research Centre for Materials Nanoarchitectonics, NIMS.
Cheng-Tien Hsieh is a Ph.D. student of National Taiwan University under the guidance of Professor Shan-hui Hsu. He obtains a fellowship from the Taiwanese government to study in the Supermolecules Group at NIMS for two years.
Shan-hui Hsu received her Ph.D. degree from Case Western Reserve University (USA) in 1992. She is now the Director and Distinguished Professor at the Institute of Polymer Science and Engineering, National Taiwan University, and Adjunct Investigator at the National Health Research Institutes, Taiwan.

several weeks culture. This type of nanoarchitectonics control on cell fates would be useful for therapeutic uses of stem cells.
Natural tissues and extracellular matrices are not purely rigid but exhibit stress relaxation. Recent attention is paid to nonlinear mechanics such as viscoelastic materials, in order to more closely mimic in vivo tissue mechanics. Chaudhuri and coworkers investigated the effect of extracellular matrix stress relaxation on cell behaviors on the basis of experiments and computational modelling.[20] Cell spreading on soft substrates that exhibit stress relaxation is greater than cell spreading on elastic substrates of the same modulus due to adhesion ligand clustering. The obtained results suggested important roles of extracellular matrix stress on cell mechano-transduction and how cells sense and respond to the extracellular matrix.
Charrier et al. clarified the influence of viscous dissipation on cell phenotype through independently tuning elastic and viscous moduli in polyacrylamide hydrogel with viscoelastic properties similar to soft tissues.[21] Viscous dissipation alone tends to decrease cell spreading if it cannot be overcome by a local clustering of adhesion proteins allowed by plastic remodeling. Independently tuning of elasticity and viscous dissipation revealed that viscosity would modulate the effect of elasticity on cell. The observed facts would be also important for some kinds of pathologies. Shifts of tissue viscoelasticity may accompany with disease progression in cases of cancer and fibrosis.
Nanoarchitectonics approach on tuning the rate of stress relaxation of hydrogels was reported by Mooney and coworkers.[22] It was found that cell spreading, proliferation, and osteogenic differentiation of mesenchymal stem cells are all enhanced in three-dimensional (3D) culture in hydrogels with a faster relaxation. The effects of stress relaxation are mediated by adhesion-ligand binding, actomyosin contractility and mechanical clustering of adhesion ligands. The reported findings again confirm key roles of stress relaxation in interaction between extracellular matrices and cells which
provide useful imprecations for parameter designs in biomaterials nanoarchitectonics for cell culture.
Roca-Cusachs, Salmeron-Sancheza, and co-workers used supported lipid bilayers as an idealized system with purely viscous natures without an elastic contribution.[23] Cells sense viscosity through focal adhesions to its overall effect on cell fate/differentiation (Figure 3). For example, cell size and
cytoskeletal organization are changed in proportion to viscosity of the surfaces. Molecular clutch model can explain these observations. Cells response to the pure viscous surface by the actin-talin-integrin-fibronectin clutch similarly to the pure elastic surface. A higher force loading rate at a higher viscous surface would promote the exposure of mechanosensitive proteins, activate downstream pathways. Fine nanoarchitectonics tuning on viscoelastic properties of materials surfaces would enable us to control the desired cellular response.

sections.heading: 2.2. Cells at Liquid Interface
sections.text:
As an extreme surface microenvironment from the viewpoint of viscoelasticity, liquid–liquid interfaces have been used as cell culture substrates. Giaever and Keese proved that fibroblasts can be cultured on the liquid-liquid interface between the aqueous culture medium and various fluorocarbon liquids.[24] Growth patterns of murine cell lines 3T3-L1 and SV-T2 can be altered significantly when adsorbed serum proteins at the interface were crosslinked with glutaraldehyde or the use of charge-charge interactions between protein molecules and polylysine. At the liquid-liquid interface of aqueous culture medium and fluorocarbon layer, the cell growth patterns are different from those at conventional solid substrates. Cells at the liquid-liquid interface tended to clump into isolated aggregates. In another case, confluent cell monolayers with
Figure 2. Phenotypes of stem cells are highly sensitive to tissue-level
elasticity: brain-like soft material matrices for neurogenic, muscle-mimic stiffer matrices for myogenic, and collagenous bone indicative rigid matrices for osteogenic differentiation.

lake-like openings were formed. These growth patterns are related with the capability of cell to stress and break the protein monolayer.
They also demonstrated anchorage-dependent cell growth on microcarriers of fluorocarbon fluid, which were formed by emulsification and stabilized with polylysine.[25] Such a system facilitates massive culture of cells by providing a relatively large surface area for cell growth in a small volume, allowing efficient utilization of medium. Attachment and spreading of cells were also observed on emulsified silicone oil droplets. However, the superiority of fluorocarbon phase over the other liquids were confirmed with respect to cell growth efficiency and emulsion stability.
Regulation of cell differentiation is possible at a liquid-liquid interface where viscoelastic stress would possibly become absent. Minami et al. reported controls of myogenic differentiation using C2C12 myoblast cells at liquid-liquid interfaces between aqueous culture medium and various liquid fluorocarbons (Figure 4).[26] At that interface, expression of myogenin, myogenic regulatory factors family gene was significantly suppressed even when reduction of growth factor levels induced expression of MyoD proteins. These findings indicated that the fluidic microenvironment with less mechanical stress would suppress myogenic differentiation. In addition, Langmuir-Blodgett (LB) type transfer of living cells from the liquidliquid interface to a solid substrate as LB films of living creatures is achieved. Combination of cell culture at liquid interfaces and LB technique would have interesting contributions to tissue engineering.
Jia et al. investigated spreading and growth of anchoragedependent cells such as human mesenchymal stem cells at interfaces of aqueous culture medium and fluidic fluorocarbon phase.[27] Close observations revealed spontaneous formation of monomolecular protein nanosheet through self-assembling process at water-fluorocarbon interfaces (Figure 5). The liquidliquid interface with protein nanosheet is capable of supporting spreading of human mesenchymal stem cells without additional
treatments. Upon contact with the protein nanosheets formed at the liquid-liquid interface, human mesenchymal stem cells can sense and perceive the biophysical cues. Therefore, nanoarchitectonics tuning on mechanical characteristics of the protein nanosheet structures upon regulation of protein packing would be an important key to regulate cell spreading. Various cell events including spreading, focal adhesion growth, and yes-associated protein (YAP) nuclear translocation can be triggered upon contact with the protein nanosheet. These cell behaviors can be interpreted by molecular clutch model. The ultrathin protein nanosheets have soft natures with incredibly flexible and easily deformable characteristics and are perceived by cells as being much softer. Therefore, cell culture systems at liquid-liquid interfaces would open a way for novel cell science and technology with extremely soft materials.
Gautrot and co-workers reported the control of cell adhesion and expansion by protein nanosheet on low-viscosity liquids.[28] With addition of reactive surfactant pentafluorobenzoyl chloride, the mechanics of protein layer is enhanced, which can promote cell adhesion and proliferation. The same research team reported expansion and fate decision of stem cells with self-assembled nanosheets.[29] The used polymer nanosheets was made from cationic poly(L-lysine) and reactive surfactant pentafluorobenzoyl chloride, to which extracellular matrix protein can be adsorbed. With strong mechanical properties, cell spreading and proliferation can be controlled.
Figure 4. Control of myogenic differentiation of C2 C12 myoblasts at liquid–
liquid interfaces between aqueous culture medium and various liquid fluorocarbons.

sections.heading: 3.1. Dynamic Regulation
sections.text:
Cell functions and fates can be controlled through dynamic regulation of materials surface nanoarchitectonics. Dynamic modulation of biophysical and biochemical properties of synthetic extracellular matrix is sometimes effective. Through patterning the presentation of the extracellular matrix protein vitronectin using two bioorthogonal photochemistries, DeForest and Tirrell accomplished reversible differentiation of human mesenchymal stem cells to osteoblasts in a spatially defined manner.[30] Based on their materials nanoarchitectonics, target proteins can be immobilized with defined amount though sequential processes of photodeprotection and oxime ligation. The proteins can be in turn removed by photoscission of orthonitrobenzyl esters. Differentiation of human mesenchymal stem cells to osteoblasts was regulated upon these photochemical patterning of the extracellular matrix protein vitronectin.
Wei, Deng and co-workers have nanoarchitected a dynamic platform for guiding mesenchymal stem cells differentiation on the basis of reversible electrochemical switching of a polypyrrole array between highly adhesive hydrophobic nanotubes and poorly adhesive hydrophilic nanotips (Figure 6).[31] Changes of cell adhesive capability have significant influences on mechanotransduction activation to regulate mesenchymal stem cells differentiation. Multiple cycles between attachment and detachment of mesenchymal stem cells to the polypyrrole array
induce activation of intracellular mechanotransduction and osteogenic differentiation. These processes can be accomplished independently from surface stiffness and chemical induction. This research exhibits a nice example of nanoarchitectonics for regulation of stimuli-responsive materials and stem cells.
Thermally responsive control of stem cell fate was demonstrated by Li, Haag, and co-workers who used cross-linked hydrogels of thermosensitive electrospun microfibers.[32] Multiple cycles of thermo-induced mechanical switching from stiff (37 °C) to soft (25 °C),induced an increase of the spreading area and the polarization of human mesenchymal stem cells. The human mesenchymal stem cells with thermal mechanical stimulations exhibited enhanced cell spreading, adhesion, mechanical threshold for nuclear translocation of YAP signaling, and osteogenic differentiation as compared to the human mesenchymal stem cells cultured under normal conditions. These reversible and dynamic mechanical stimulation processes would become useful key processes for tissue engineering.
Bian and co-workers demonstrated an in-situ reversible heterodimeric nanoswitch controlled by dynamic Mg2+- bisphosphonate ligand coordination.[33] The proposed metal-ionbased in-situ reversible nanoswitch with presentation of celladhesive Mg2+, provides reversible cell adhesion and release in a spatiotemporal manner. It also promoted focal adhesion, spreading, and differentiation of stem cells. One of advantages of this strategy is the modular nature to utilize various bioactive nanostructures through metal-ion-ligand coordination to control various cell functions.
They also developed another type of heterodimeric nanoswitch which consists of a magnetic nanocage coupled to a gold nanoparticle coated with Arg-Gly-Asp peptide through a long flexible linker.[34] The motion of magnetic nanocage was magnetically controlled to induce a reversible uncaging/ caging of the Arg-Gly-Asp peptide, which regulate accessibility of the peptide for integrin binding. Adhesion, spreading, differentiation, and mechanosensing of stem cells can be controlled by these dynamic processes.

sections.heading: 3.2. Regulation by Chemistry and Geometry
sections.text:
Attentions have been recently paid to regulation of stem cells by simple chemistry (chemical structures of functional groups. It is regarded as an emerging area where much remains to be understood about the underlying mechanisms. Anseth and coworkers investigated differentiation of human mesenchymal stem cells encapsulated in polyethylene glycol hydrogel with covalently immobilized chemical groups such as amino, tertbutyl, phosphate, fluoro, and carboxylic acid groups.[35] Such simple chemical nanoarchitectonics can potentially regulate differentiation and induce multiple lineages of human mesenchymal stem cells.
Chemical nanoarchitectonics for regulation of various cell behaviors is widely investigated. Because cellular signal transduction is based on sophisticated networks of molecular events, chemical nanoarchitectonics of key chemicals can modulate
Figure 6. A dynamic platform for differentiation of mesenchymal stem cells
on the basis of reversibly electrochemical switching of a polypyrrole array between highly adhesive hydrophobic nanotubes and poorly adhesive hydrophilic nanotips.

various cell functions. For example, Katayama summarized in his recent review article the use of a peptide grafted polymer as artificial converters of cellular signals.[36] Polymer grafted with cationic peptides as substrates of target protease and protein kinase can activate transgene transcription upon particular signals. Yu, Tsai, and co-workers investigated the formation of spheroid from human adipose-derived stem cells on surface coated with nanoarchitected polymers with sulfobetaine methacrylate, butyl methacrylate, and hydroxyethyl methacrylate moieties.[37] Because spheroid formations, stem cells are capable of activating their functionality and enhancing their therapeutic potential, this approach would have good contributions to stem cell spheroid applications. He and Xu introduced their novel strategy based on instructed-assembly to regulate biological events in cells trough the shifts of equilibrium upon stimuli responsive supramolecular superstructures.[38] Supramolecular assemblies through instructedassembly are sometimes capable of mimicking soft dynamic extracellular matrices. For example, regulation of cell spheroids through instructed-assembly of glycopeptides and phosphopeptides was demonstrated.
As geometric effects on cell regulation, Mrksich and coworkers demonstrated the strong influence of cell shape on differentiation of human mesenchymal stem cells from bone marrow.[39] They used microcontact printing technique to fabricate desired shapes of hydrophobic island within hydrophilic surface. On the patterned surface, extracellular matrix protein fibronectin adsorbed only onto the hydrophobic islands, resulting in shapedefined cell adhesion. Cells cultures on rectangle patterns with different aspect ratios and cultured on symmetric pentagonal patterns with various subcellular curvature exhibited altered adipogenesis and osteogenesis profiles upon exposure to competing soluble differentiation signals. Osteogenesis was promoted when actomyosin contractility was geometrically increased. Geometric factors affect mechanochemical signals and paracrine/ autocrine factors in harmonized ways, resulting in fate decision of human mesenchymal stem cells.
Goldoni, Stevens, and co-workers reported regulation of cell signaling upon cell geometry through modulation on the nanoscale ordering of plasma membrane order.[40] Human mesenchymal stem cells were cultured on micropatterned surfaces with fibronectin in circular, triangular, and square shape. Cell contractility among these shapes was analyzed, and their shape-dependent stiffness was evaluated by atomic force microscopy. Cell signaling involving the serine/threonine kinase Akt/protein kinase B was triggered by changes of biophysical properties depending on cell geometries, resulting in geometry-dependent differentiation of mesenchymal stem cells. The obtained results suggest the role of plasma membrane ordered lipid raft microdomains for modulation of stem cell differentiation.

sections.heading: 4. Nanoarchitectonics for Cell: Approach with Nanotopography
sections.text:
As mentioned above, cell behaviors and fate decisions are regulated by many factors such as surface viscoelastic proper-
ties, dynamic changes of surface aspects, exposed chemical groups, and geometries. Such features can be also regulated with major nanoarchitectonics methods, nano/micro-fabrication and supramolecular assembly.

sections.heading: 4.1. Nano/Micro-Fabrication for Cell Regulation
sections.text:
Liu and co-workers investigated the effect of the size of nanoobjects arrays on differentiation of human adipose-derived stem cells using fabricated nanopillar arrays of biodegradable polylactic acid with different diameters (Figure 7).[41] Their research revealed that the nanopillar array with a diameter of 200 nm efficiently promoted osteogenic differentiation of human adipose-derived stem cells in absence of any growth factors or osteogenic-induced medium. Similarly, the 200 nm sized pillar array also showed an improved ectopic osteogenic ability on in vivo animal models. Such nanoarchitected nanoarrays of degradable biopolymers with designed shapes and arrangements would be useful for various biomedical events

including restoration of tooth enamel, spine fusion, and bone crack repair.
Neural differentiation of human mesenchymal stem cells using photo-lithographically fabricated nanoarchitectures with metal electrodeposition was investigated by Kelley and coworkers.[42] Cell alignment was promoted with the nanofabricated substrates, inducing efficient neurogenic differentiation with significant expression of microtubule-associated protein 2 (MAP2), as evidenced by immunostaining and gene expression analysis. Neuronal differentiation was efficiently promoted by highly spiky structures. The observed results indicated that surface nanostructures would become an important key factor to promote neurogenesis.
Dalby et al. used electron beam lithography to fabricate both surface nanostructures with highly ordered symmetries and those with different level of disorders to investigate the effect of nanoscale symmetry and disorder on differentiation of human mesenchymal stem cells.[43] Nanoscale disorders were demonstrated to stimulate differentiation of human mesenchymal stem cells to produce bone mineral without the aid of osteogenic supplements. The stem cells in a topographically controlled medium showed a distinct differentiation profiles as compared with those in regular osteogenic medium. In another work, Gadegaard, Dalby and co-workers demonstrated the long-term preservation of phenotype and multipotency of human mesenchymal stem cells.[44] A prolonged retention of human mesenchymal stem cell markers and multipotency was achieved through cultures on specifically fabricated surface with an absolute square lattice symmetry. This work also suggested that small RNAs may suppress key cell signaling and metabolomic pathways.

sections.heading: 4.2. Self-Assembly for Cell Regulation
sections.text:
Preparation methods of nano/micro structures for cell regulations are not limited to fabrication techniques. Self-assembly processes to create various morphologies and hierarchic structures from unit molecules and materials are indeed a powerful methodology in nanoarchitectonics approaches. For example, Shrestha and coworkers have been reporting the synthesis of various structures from simple zero-dimensional molecular units, fullerenes, by liquid-liquid interfacial precipitation method,[45] following pioneering research efforts by Miyazawa.[46] Some of the fullerene assembled structures and their higher assemblies have been used for cell regulations.
Minami et al. investigated the control of macroscopic orientation and the differentiation of mouse skeletal myoblast C2C12 cells into muscle cells (Figure 8).[47] One-dimensional fullerene nanowhiskers (ca. 300 nm in diameter and ca. 170 μm in length) were first prepared by precipitation at interface of isopropyl alcohol and a saturated toluene solution of C60. The resulting C60 nanowhiskers were spread on the air-water interface and compressed, followed by transfer to a solid substrate by conventional LB technique. These simple processes provide highly aligned arrays of one-dimensional nanocarbon assembly (fullerene nanowhiskers) on various kinds of solid substrates
regardless of hydrophilic or hydrophobic materials with high surface coverages. Cultures of mouse skeletal myoblast C2C12 cells on the aligned fullerene nanowhiskers promoted differentiation to myotube formation. The advantageous features of this method including promoted differentiation, controlled cell spreading direction, large fabrication area and biocompatibility, would suggest high potential of the proposed strategy for tissue engineering.
Krishnan et al. proposed an advanced vortex LangmuirBlodgett (vortex LB) method to regulate the orientation of cell growth using C60 nanowhisker arrays with controlled aligned curvature.[48] In the vortex LB method, one-dimensional fullerene nanowhiskers are aligned at the air-water interface upon vortex flow by rotation of water phase (Figure 9A). Packing densities and geometries of nanowhisker arrays together with their curvatures can be regulated by control of the rotation rate, the nature of transfer substrates, and the lifting position. The curvature of aligned arrays of fullerene nanowhiskers is easily adjustable by selecting the transfer position (large curvature close to the rotation center and small curvature far away from the rotating center). The culture of bone-forming human osteoblast MG63 cells on the prepared solid substrate exhibited controllable growth direction of the cells.
Recently, Hsu and co-workers have developed unidirectional shaking methods to obtain highly aligned one-dimensional fullerene nanowhiskers (Figure 9B).[49] Then, neural stem cells were cultured on the fabricated highly aligned nanowhisker arrays. Although, cell viability on aligned fullerene nanowhiskers is slightly inferior to that on randomly dispersed fullerene nanowhiskers. The significant up-regulation with β-tubulin as

immature neuron gene marker and MAP2 as mature neuron gene marker was confirmed for neural stem cells cultured on the highly aligned fullerene nanowhiskers as compared with those with random nanowhisker assemblies. The fate of neural stem cells is clearly regulated by aligned structures of selfassembled fullerene nanowhiskers.
Shapes of fullerene assembly by the liquid-liquid interfacial precipitation are not limited to one-dimensional objects such as nanowhiskers and nanotubes. Two-dimensional polygon nanosheets with hexagonal and rectangle shapes,[50] three-dimensional nano cubes,[51] and hierarchic structures[52] can be obtained by adjusting solvent systems and precipitation conditions. Hsu and co-workers demonstrated the use of fullerene C60 hexagonal nanosheets transferred on a solid substrate and covered with Pluronic 123 triblock-copolymer (polyethylene glycol-polypropylene glycol-polyethyleneglycol) for optogenetic modulation and reprogramming of bacteriorhodopsin–transfected human fibroblasts.[53] A high coverage of fullerene nanosheets induced a slower cell proliferation rate and a more pronounced cell differentiation into glial cells or neurons. The fullerene nanosheets may assist transmission of the electron signal into the cells, resulting in a higher neuron differentiation. In addition, light stimulation also has a promoting effect on reprogramming and differentiation of human fibroblasts into neural-like cells. This method can provide a new optogenetic platform for spatiotemporal regulation of cell regulations by a selective location of fullerene nanosheets and light irradiation timing.
Self-grown nanostructures can be used for cell regulations. Ji et al. prepared upright nanosheet network through a hydro-
thermal self-grown process from silica surface for gene reverse transfection (Figure 10).[54] The upright nanosheet network was spontaneously formed on silica-coated silicon wafer surface by incubation in aqueous NaBH4 solution at 75 °C. The nanosheets have a thickness of several nanometers and their network structures possess continuous porous motifs, which are advantageous for DNA immobilization and cell contact. Direct gene transfection (reverse transfection) to human embryonic kidney cells with much enhanced efficiency was demonstrated without using recombinant proteins. Hsu and co-workers applied this strategy for the delivery of naked plasmid DNA into human mesenchymal stem cells.[55] The noncytotoxic nature of nanosheets were confirmed by a high survival rate of cells. Structural factor of the nanosheet, aspect ratio between height and thickness of the sheet walls, are significantly influential with transfection efficiency. Hsu and co-workers also demonstrated a promoted transfection of naked plasmid DNA (GATA4) into human mesenchymal stem cells with more detailed gene expression analyses.[56] The proposed method gives a higher gene transfection efficiency with a safe and naturally abundant silica as transfection substrates.

sections.heading: 5. Future Perspectives
sections.text:
Control and regulation of living cells are important subjects for the improvement of our life activities especially from biomedical viewpoints. Not limited to examples shown here, continuous efforts on this target have been expensively made.[57] Efforts for cell regulations are not related only with advancement of biology and biotechnology but also with chemistry, physics, material science and nanotechnology. In most cases, various interactions at interfaces between cells and materials have central roles in cell behaviors such as growth, proliferation, and differentiation. Therefore, nanoarchitectonics efforts to construct interfacial structures and controls of their dynamic
Figure 9. Alignment methods of fullerene nanowhiskers for cell control: (A)
vortex Langmuir-Blodgett method; (B) unidirectional shaking method.

motions and functions in materials science and supramolecular chemistry are crucial for cell regulation, as exemplified in this review article. Nanoarchitectonics at interfaces is undoubtedly important for cell regulations.
As more advanced progresses in the related fields, fusion of other functions into cell regulations at interfacial environments are expected. For example, regulation of artificial molecular machines and molecular receptors at interfaces have been recently researched,[58] where faintly tuning their properties and performances including molecular capture,[59] biomolecule discrimination,[60] molecular rotor motion,[61] and molecular pliers opening/closure[62] becomes possible through mechanical stimuli and environmental alterations of interfacial membrane media. Molecular machine activities can be integrated into cell activities at interfaces. As one pioneering work, García-López demonstrated opening a hole at cell membranes with the action of a molecular motor.[63] Such integration of man-made micro/nano machines with living cell activities would lead to target therapy for cancer cells etc. Fantastic voyage would be realistic in near future with developments of these sciences and technologies.
